words.meaning: Not explicit or direct in addressing a point; slanting.
examples: He made an oblique reference to his rival's past failures.
The lines in the painting were oblique, creating a sense of dynamic movement.

words.meaning: Deviation from moral rectitude or sound thinking; indirectness or deliberate obscurity.
examples: The politician's speech was full of obliquity and half-truths.
His moral obliquity was evident in his dishonest business dealings.

words.meaning: To destroy utterly; wipe out.
examples: The bombing raid threatened to obliterate the entire city.
She wanted to obliterate all memory of her painful past.

words.meaning: The state of being unaware or unconscious of what is happening; the state of being forgotten.
examples: The once-famous actor has now faded into oblivion.
He drank himself into oblivion after hearing the bad news.

words.meaning: Not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around one.
examples: Deep in his book, he was completely oblivious to the noise around him.
She seemed oblivious to the fact that she had offended everyone.

words.meaning: Strong public criticism or verbal abuse.
examples: The disgraced CEO faced a storm of public obloquy after the scandal broke.
He endured years of obloquy from his political opponents.

words.meaning: Extremely unpleasant; highly offensive.
examples: His obnoxious behavior at the dinner party made everyone uncomfortable.
There was an obnoxious smell coming from the garbage can.

words.meaning: Not discovered or known about; uncertain. Also, to keep from being seen; to conceal.
examples: He was an obscure writer whose work was only appreciated after his death.
The heavy fog threatened to obscure the road ahead.

words.meaning: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.
examples: The obsequious assistant was always trying to flatter his boss.
She had no patience for obsequious salespeople.

words.meaning: To preoccupy or fill the mind of (someone) continually and intrusively.
examples: He started to obsess about his weight and diet.
Don't obsess over small mistakes; just learn from them.

words.meaning: An idea or thought that continually preoccupies or intrudes on a person's mind.
examples: His obsession with collecting stamps took up all his free time.
She developed an unhealthy obsession with her favorite celebrity.

words.meaning: A hard, dark, glasslike volcanic rock formed by the rapid solidification of lava.
examples: Ancient peoples used obsidian to make sharp tools and arrowheads.
The sculpture was carved from a single piece of polished black obsidian.

words.meaning: The process of becoming outdated and no longer used.
examples: Planned obsolescence in electronics encourages consumers to buy new models frequently.
The rapid pace of technology leads to the quick obsolescence of older devices.

words.meaning: No longer produced or used; out of date.
examples: The use of floppy disks is now completely obsolete.
The company had to replace its obsolete manufacturing equipment.

words.meaning: A doctor who specializes in pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period.
examples: She chose an obstetrician who worked at the nearby hospital.
The obstetrician monitored the health of the mother and baby throughout the pregnancy.

words.meaning: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action.
examples: He was obstinate and refused to admit he was wrong, despite all the evidence.
The obstinate mule would not move an inch.

words.meaning: Noisy and difficult to control.
examples: The obstreperous children were running and shouting in the restaurant.
The teacher struggled to manage the obstreperous class.

words.meaning: A person who deliberately blocks or gets in the way of progress.
examples: The senator was accused of being an obstructionist for filibustering the bill.
Progress on the committee was stalled by a few determined obstructionists.

words.meaning: To get, acquire, or secure something.
examples: You can obtain a copy of the report from the main office.
He worked hard to obtain the necessary qualifications for the job.

words.meaning: Noticeable or prominent in an unwelcome or intrusive way.
examples: The new skyscraper was an obtrusive addition to the historic city skyline.
He had an obtrusive way of asking very personal questions.

words.meaning: Annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand.
examples: He was being deliberately obtuse, refusing to understand her point.
I'm not sure if he's genuinely obtuse or just pretending not to get it.

words.meaning: To remove a need or difficulty; to avoid or prevent.
examples: A direct flight would obviate the need for a layover.
Careful planning should obviate any last-minute problems.

words.meaning: Easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent.
examples: The answer to the riddle was obvious once he explained it.
It was obvious from her expression that she was angry.

words.meaning: To stop, close up, or obstruct an opening or passage.
examples: A buildup of plaque can occlude the arteries.
The dense fog began to occlude the view of the mountains.

words.meaning: Stopped up; blocked or obstructed.
examples: The patient required surgery for an occluded coronary artery.
The path was occluded by a large, fallen tree.

words.meaning: Relating to mystical, supernatural, or magical powers, practices, or phenomena.
examples: He had a deep interest in the occult and ancient magic.
The horror movie was filled with occult symbols and rituals.

words.meaning: A person who is from 80 to 89 years old.
examples: My grandfather, an active octogenarian, still plays golf twice a week.
The community center hosted a birthday party for the beloved octogenarian.

words.meaning: An old-fashioned term for an ophthalmologist or optometrist.
examples: In the 19th century, you would visit an oculist for eye-related problems.
The oculist prescribed a new pair of spectacles for him.

words.meaning: Extremely unpleasant; repulsive.
examples: The villain in the story was a truly odious character.
She had the odious task of cleaning out the grease trap.

words.meaning: General or widespread hatred or disgust directed toward someone as a result of their actions.
examples: The dictator's cruelty earned him the odium of the entire world.
After the scandal, he had to face the public odium.

words.meaning: Having or giving off a smell, especially an unpleasant one.
examples: The odoriferous durian fruit is banned in many public places.
A strange, odoriferous gas seeped from the chemical spill.

words.meaning: Having or giving off a smell.
examples: The garden was filled with the scent of odorous flowers.
The odorous swamp was home to many insects.

words.meaning: A long and eventful or adventurous journey or experience.
examples: His journey from a small village to becoming a CEO was a remarkable odyssey.
The book recounts the author's spiritual odyssey through India.

words.meaning: Of the best quality or the most extreme degree.
examples: The jeweler confirmed that the diamond was of the first water.
He was a scoundrel of the first water.

words.meaning: In a place where few people go; remote and isolated.
examples: They found a charming little cafe off the beaten track.
As a tourist, he preferred to explore places that were off the beaten track.

words.meaning: The entrails and internal organs of an animal used as food.
examples: The traditional Scottish dish, haggis, is made from offal.
Some cultures consider dishes made with offal a delicacy.

words.meaning: The part of a Christian service where offerings of money are collected.
examples: The choir sang a beautiful anthem during the offertory.
The money collected in the offertory supports the church's community programs.

words.meaning: Casually or coolly unconcerned; without previous thought.
examples: His offhand comment about her appearance was hurtful.
I can't tell you the exact numbers offhand, but I can find out.

words.meaning: Assertive of authority in an annoyingly domineering way, especially with regard to trivial matters.
examples: The officious security guard enjoyed telling people what to do.
She was an officious busybody, always interfering in her neighbors' lives.

words.meaning: To counteract something by having an opposing force or effect.
examples: The pay raise was intended to offset the increase in the cost of living.
He planted trees to offset his carbon emissions from flying.

words.meaning: To stare at in a lecherous or flirtatious manner.
examples: It's rude to ogle people at the beach.
The creepy man in the corner continued to ogle the young women.

words.meaning: Relating to the sense of smell.
examples: A dog's olfactory sense is far more powerful than a human's.
The smell of baking bread triggered a pleasant olfactory memory.

words.meaning: A small group of people having control of a country or organization.
examples: The nation was ruled by a corrupt oligarchy of wealthy elites.
He argued that the company was an oligarchy run by a few powerful executives.

words.meaning: Giving the impression that something bad or unpleasant is going to happen; threatening.
examples: The ominous black clouds on the horizon signaled a coming storm.
There was an ominous silence after he made his threat.

words.meaning: Someone or something that has been left out or excluded.
examples: The most notable omission from the guest list was the bride's own brother.
Her story was suspicious due to several key omissions.

words.meaning: Having unlimited power; able to do anything.
examples: In many mythologies, the chief deity is portrayed as omnipotent.
The tyrannical ruler believed he was omnipotent and beyond challenge.

words.meaning: Present everywhere at the same time.
examples: In the modern world, the influence of social media feels omnipresent.
For the paranoid man, the feeling of being watched was omnipresent.

words.meaning: The state of knowing everything.
examples: The belief in divine omniscience is a key tenet of many religions.
No human being can ever achieve true omniscience.

words.meaning: Knowing everything.
examples: The novel is told from the point of view of an omniscient narrator.
If I were omniscient, I'd know the answers to all of life's mysteries.

words.meaning: Feeding on food of both plant and animal origin; having a varied diet.
examples: Humans are omnivorous, though many choose a vegetarian or vegan diet.
She has an omnivorous taste in music, enjoying everything from classical to heavy metal.

words.meaning: In an anxious or nervous state of suspense.
examples: The entire team was on pins and needles waiting for the final results.
She was on pins and needles until she heard that her family was safe.

words.meaning: In a state of suspense or anxiety.
examples: He was on tenter hooks all day, waiting for news about the job offer.
The thrilling movie kept the audience on tenter hooks until the very end.

words.meaning: Joining others in doing or supporting something that is popular or likely to be successful.
examples: After the team won the championship, thousands of new fans jumped on the bandwagon.
Many politicians are quick to jump on the bandwagon of a popular social cause.

words.meaning: Being reprimanded by someone in authority.
examples: He was called on the carpet for missing another important deadline.
The players were on the carpet with the coach for their poor performance.

words.meaning: Exactly at the arranged time.
examples: The meeting is scheduled for 9 AM, so please be here on the dot.
He is very punctual and always arrives on the dot.

words.meaning: On the alert; vigilant.
examples: The security guards were on the qui vive for any signs of trouble.
As a journalist, you always have to be on the qui vive for a good story.

words.word: on the spur of the moment
words.meaning: Done as a result of a sudden impulse, without premeditation.
examples: They decided to fly to Paris on the spur of the moment.
On the spur of the moment, he quit his job and bought a boat.

words.meaning: Very rarely.
examples: An opportunity like this comes along only once in a blue moon.
I only get to see my cousins from Australia once in a blue moon.

words.word: one swallow doesn't make a summer
words.meaning: A single positive event is not a reliable indicator of a general trend.
examples: The company's stock went up today, but one swallow doesn't make a summer.
He was nice to me once, but I know that one swallow doesn't make a summer.

words.meaning: (Of a task or duty) involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome.
examples: He found the responsibility of caring for his elderly parents to be an onerous task.
The paperwork for the visa application was long and onerous.
